pros: Great people, passionate, good opportunities, good balance, rewarding job
cons: There are no downsides of working at this company

review_title: Excellent organization, great for early career learning, tougher for middle career, excellent again for senior positions
pros: Meaningful work.  Thin layer of bureaucracy.  Focus on professional development.  Family atmosphere with lots of long time staff in the system.  Great opportunity to grow in responsibility and learn about various sides of international development.
cons: Few career paths from entry level into mid-career positions unless one goes abroad to the field offices.  Being reliant on US gov funding means that every few years things get tight until new grants are secured.

review_title: Truly one of the best workplaces
pros: Superb organizational culture: warm, welcoming, humanistic, informal, down-to-earth, combined with relatively high individual flexibility and autonomy. Excellent benefits. Mission is devoted to improving education and health care equity. Bright, talented workforce across the board: 99% have a college degree; many have graduate degrees.
cons: Although one's ongoing professional development is supported, there's not a really a career ladder. Most employees are hired for a specific role in a specific project; the opportunity to "move up" within a project is very rare. Also, projects are funded by soft money (federal and state agencies; foundations); when the funding goes away, so does the job.

pros: The individuals are absolutely wonderful to work with and each division feels like a tight knit community. There are several perks such as internal professional development workshops, company-wide mixers, great resources, company raffles, and education reimbursements, which is very rare for a non-profit.
cons: There isn't a lot of opportunity for growth from entry-level to middle-level, and middle-level is almost nonexistent. While your work schedule can be flexible, workloads are overwhelming for many.  Annual raises are the bare minimum. Management is not very diverse and they could use some diversity and inclusion training.

pros: Great learning environment and very supportive. You get a lot of experience in a lot of different baskets (business dev., M&E, finance, Admin). Direct interaction with the VP and President of the organization. Lots of responsibilities that would typically be given to someone at a higher level once you've proven yourself capable.
cons: It is a somewhat static organization in that there isn't a ton of room for growth in Boston. It requires movement to a field office or staying a PO position until something comes up. There isn't a natural progression as there might be in a larger org.

pros: great people, energy and corp culture in general.  innovation and initiative are encouraged
cons: overlap with JSI can be confusing outside and in some areas leadership not ready for change and while innovation encouraged, little support except for a few stars

pros: Great people, very friendly and nice to work with. Laid back environment
cons: Terrible management,  academic professors are hired as VPs to manage divisions. They are mostly clueless about management practices or strategic operations.

pros: Great working environment. There is a lot of teamwork and encouragement to collaborate across divisions. Also, great benefits and opportunity to learn and grow.
cons: Low salary, but expected at nonprofit orgs
